facts.text: Respondent appointed in 1948 as Memandari, that is, Superintendent of State Guest Houses, in the State of Junagadh when it was administered by the Government of India, and was later confirmed in that appointment.
In 1949, Junagadh became integrated into the State of Saurashtra, and thereafter the services of the respondent were continued by that State, and he was appointed from time to time to various posts.
On June 15, 1950, respondent was appointed Sales Tax Officer, Madhya Saurashtra, Rajkot.
Respondent was confirmed as Sales Tax Officer on April 16, 1952.
Respondent was 50 years old on October 30, 1952.

On October 30, 1952, the Government of Saurashtra, purporting to act under Government Resolution No. 60 of 1948 as it then stood (amended R. 165-A), passed an order compulsorily terminating his services.

Respondent filed a writ application in the High Court of Saurashtra (Civil Miscellaneous Application No. 52 of 1953), challenging the validity of the October 30, 1952 order on the ground that it was made without notice of any charge of misconduct or inefficiency and without enquiry, in contravention of Art. 311(2).
High Court of Saurashtra by judgment and order dated February 26, 1954, upheld the contention, set aside the order as one of dismissal without enquiry, illegal and void.
Appeal preferred to Supreme Court on certificate under Art. 133(1)(c).
Rule 161 of Bombay Civil Services Rules (adopted by Saurashtra): compulsory retirement age 55 years for non-inferior servants, may be retained after with sanction.

Original R. 165-A: Competent authority may remove or retire on misconduct, insolvency, inefficiency, but proviso requires procedure in Note 1 to Rule 33 (referring to Rule 55: notice, charges, enquiry).

R. 165-A amended September 28, 1950 and January 15, 1952: Proviso and Note not to apply; Government retains absolute right to retire after 25 years qualifying service or 50 years age without reason, no claim to compensation; right not exercised except in public interest like inefficiency or dishonesty.
Under rules, age of superannuation is 55 years.
No such claim under Junagadh rules (superannuation 60) or Instrument of Accession raised in writ petition.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order of compulsory retirement under amended R. 165-A before age of superannuation (55) is one of dismissal or removal within Art. 311(2), requiring enquiry.
Whether amended R. 165-A, authorising termination without reason or enquiry after 50 years/25 years service, is ultra vires Art. 311(2).
Whether Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh applies, distinguishing based on rule mentioning inefficiency/dishonesty implying stigma.

petitioner_arguments.text: The order dated October 30, 1952 is within scope of amended R. 165-A as respondent had attained 50 years; valid unless rule ultra vires; Shyam Lal applies, compulsory retirement not dismissal/removal under Art. 311(2).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Amended R. 165-A; Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh [1953] SCR 26

petitioner_arguments.text: No claim under Junagadh rules or Instrument of Accession raised in writ petition.

respondent_arguments.text: Order is in effect dismissal without notice/enquiry, violating Art. 311(2); R. 165-A ultra vires as authorises termination without reason/enquiry.
Shyam Lal does not apply as R. 165-A unlike Note I to Art. 465-A, states right not exercised except on inefficiency/dishonesty, implying stigma/imputation of misconduct/incapacity, thus dismissal.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh [1953] SCR 26 (observations on stigma)

respondent_arguments.text: Under Junagadh rules, superannuation 60; Art. XVI Instrument of Accession protects conditions.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Junagadh rules; Art. XVI Instrument of Accession; Bholanath J. Thaker v. State of Saurashtra

court_reasoning.text: Compulsory retirement not dismissal/removal under Art. 311(2); criterion is whether it involves loss of benefits previously earned (pension proportionate to service entitled, unlike dismissal/removal which are punitive and forfeit pension).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order of retirement differs from dismissal/removal as not punishment, no penal consequences.

court_reasoning.text: Shyam Lal applies; R. 165-A provision on not exercising except inefficiency/dishonesty is departmental instruction, not imposing fetter or stigma; misconduct/inefficiency furnish background but no formal enquiry required unlike dismissal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No imputation/charge made condition; absolute right retained.

court_reasoning.text: R. 165-A intra vires Art. 311(2); order under it valid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Policy of Art. 311(2) is protection against punishment entailing forfeiture of benefits.

court_reasoning.text: Claim under Junagadh rules too late, not raised in writ.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No such claim put forward in writ petition.

holdings.text: Order of compulsory retirement under R. 165-A is not dismissal or removal under Art. 311(2); no enquiry required.
Amended R. 165-A is intra vires Art. 311(2).
Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh governs; retirement order valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Compulsory retirement not dismissal/removal under Art. 311(2); no stigma even if background of misconduct/inefficiency.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh
Bholanath J. Thaker v. State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Relied on by respondent for superannuation age protection; rejected as not raised below.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 311(2) protects against dismissal/removal without enquiry; does not apply to compulsory retirement without loss of accrued benefits.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Civil Services Rules
sections: Rule 55 (Civil Services Classification, Control and Appeal Rules, 1930)
statutes_cited.relevance: Rule 161: superannuation at 55; R.165-A (amended): absolute right to retire after 50/25 years without reason/enquiry, except public interest (inefficiency etc.); Rule 55: enquiry procedure for dismissal/removal.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment and order of Saurashtra High Court dated February 26, 1954 set aside; respondent's writ petition dismissed; order of retirement dated October 30, 1952 upheld as valid.

key_quotes.text: "The real criterion for deciding whether an order terminating the services of a servant is one of dismissal or removal is to ascertain whether it involves any loss of benefits previously earned."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core test distinguishing retirement from dismissal/removal under Art. 311(2).

key_quotes.text: "There can be no doubt that removal... generally implies that the officer is regarded as in some manner blameworthy or deficient... Such grounds... involve the levelling of some imputation or charge against the officer."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Shyam Lal; clarifies no stigma in compulsory retirement.

key_quotes.text: "Government retains an absolute right to retire any Government servant after he has completed 25 years qualifying service or 50 years of age, whatever the service without giving any reason..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of amended R. 165-A upholding the power.
